Topic.Title: Price Needs To Retest 435 Support..

Message.Msg: It is just pathetic that this company allows this kind of deterioration in the value of its stock. Just as you begin to think it couldn't possibly drop any more, it precisely does that. Look at comapnies like txn, intc and msft. They all have lower growth and earnings and yet their pes are much higher. Why,? Because they have been able to attract value investors. Aapl is not interested in that because first, it views itself as the undisputed king of innovation and, second, it simply doesn't care much about shareholders. If there's no innovation, the company has to return some money to its shareholders-just as the afformentioned companies are doing. I urge all the levelheaded longs to read two recent articles that deal with those issues in a straightforward and concise way- What Apple Must do to Soar Again (on Google), and Why Apple Shares Lagged Today (on Yahoo). These two writers speak the truth.

Topic.Title: Futures are up this am

Message.Msg: well... we had some damage to the normal pattern of all the time up up up since fiasco cliff... that pattern is broken... we also have a small short on as a starter position but that can be erased and we might be forced to go re-long again... could have been a head-fake at the lows yesterday... also most of the internals showed some change in status that were once always strong have crossed over to negative... we also lost 3 of 7 indicators and 2 of them on the same day yesterday... market had been pumped up to an overbought condition... when you have that type of cocktail mix it can go sour on what typically used to work for us... like a friday-after-lunch-hold-market-generally-up-status... but what if the indicators head-faked us and then take us back to the long-entry forcing us to reverse out of the short and into the long... then we can apply that friday-after-lunch-hold-market-generally-up-status again but only if those indicators turn up again and remove our short-stature... yesterday someone said it right, very smart man, argtam... so much outside influence make this market so much harder to read... anything can happen... and he don't wanna play that game... and he right... if it goes up then your account grows a little more and you really don't jump for joy as much as you did... but if it go down hard then you cry a river... the sting of the bee hurt

The World's poor and multitudes in third world may want the cheapest phones, and alot of Android Phones are given for $0 for a contract with monthly fee... but they are more prone to hacker attack and viruses, than Apple IOS based phones. Topic.Title: Seeking Alpha-- Will Apple Be Around in Three Yrs?? .... who

Message.Msg: Right, but the reality is is that two things have to happen for a technology leader to completely fall from grace. First, there must be a competing innovation that is demonstrably better than the incumbent leader, and, second, the current leader must be doing multiple things to offend its existing customer base. Both must happen. Now, if you believe what I say above, then you can apply it to Apple and see if both hold true. In my opinion, there is no great innovation by a competitor that is demonstrably better than Apples products in their respective categories. So that checks off for now as safe, unless someone wants to offer up an example. As far as offending their customer, well, I suppose you could make a case on price for iDevices, but price differentials when they do exist is not driven by Apples offensive actions, but more so by competitors willingness to sell at or below cost or competitors prices being subsidized by Googles search revenues and profits. Category by category it is hard to see an actual example of where Apple might be offending its customer. In fact, I would argue they are doing a pretty good job serving them. I suppose you could also point out screen size for smartphones and open vs. closed systems, but Apple has already shown the willingness to change with the introduction of the iPad mini and a 4 inch screen on the phone. The debate over closed versus open is not in reality an offensive point with consumers. Both are legitimate approaches with trade offs of positives and negatives. Again, past tech leaders have fallen from grace mainly for two reasons: a competing innovation passing them by, and a companies unwillingness to correct offending acts against its customers.

Message.Title: AAPL are or are not owners fickle?
Message.Msg: "The industry that Apple operates in is notoriously fickle, cutthroat, cruel and unforgiving." That's not how it seems to me. I would say that the market that Apple operates in is famously NON-fickle. More so than any other market actually. How many FORMER Apple owners do you know? Not many, I suspect. People who buy consumer electronics of the kind that Apple manufactures are famously sticky; not at all fickle. Once people 'go Apple', they don't go back; or go anywhere else. People who are buying cheaper competing products (bringing little or no margin to those competing companies) are not former Apple consumers. More importantly, they were never likely to be Apple costumers - at least not at this stage in their life as a consumer. Maybe later. And that's the key. Apple has made a fortune in the middle of the second greatest worldwide recession in a century. Imagine how its sales will improve in a non-recessionary economy? to say nothing of how it might fare in an actually healthy economy? I'll take that bet.

Topic.Title: Fundamental research method

Message.Msg: Einhorn imagines Apple issuing one or more "iPrefs" with a face value of $50 to shareholders for each common share owned. Each iPref would pay a $0.50/share quarterly dividend, and would be publicly traded. The iPrefs would yield more than Microsoft and IBM's long-term debt, and the Fed's zero interest rate policy "creates enormous demand for safe income," Einhorn argues.

Message.Msg: Well, if Apple ends up paying 6% real div rate, that'd be something. I don't personally think that'll happen, though. Mgmt won't want to turn over that high a rate, with their upcoming plans of U.S. manufacturing sites to come. They'll want to allocate cash flows to the buildout, and to R&D ... which i think they should do. With Apple's talent pool, R&D is a better investment. However, i do think the div rate should go up, something like 3-4%. Perhaps 6% (or higher) would be supportable down the road, say in 4-5 years.

Topic.Title: CNBC' New Name

Message.Msg: I suppose I'm closer to agreeing w/ this than I have been in the past--and I have friends who believe this. I agree that there is 'Brain washing,' you get NO argument from me there...although, there too, I confess, I'm likely to blame the little guys for the ease w/ which they adapt group think. I am not impressed by the sophistication of computerized trading: show me 5, or 10 year chart of any stock out there and I'll tell you I was free to buy or sell at any point along those price charts--I don't buy millions of shares so the programs don't bother to get ahead of my trades, no one cares about my small $3-50K orders. I am an option trader and I admit I've seen what looks like short term manipulation to curiously round numbers: but here it occurs to me that if you think this is happening you might place your bets accordingly (if you can't beat em, join em). I haven't seen any naked shorts but I am against betting by banks, and believe they ought not to be allowed so much leverage because I fear they will not be responsible when it goes bad: I'm against too big to fail, against bailouts and against behavior that tends to lead to gov bailouts.

Message.Title: The important thing about the new iWatch is the word "new"
Message.Msg: What it does will matter, of course, but for the stock it's about innovation and this will help. Everyone knows it will be good. The iPad was predicted to be a huge flop and we saw how that worked out. In fact I remember when the Mac was considered a wanna-be and the iPod was dissed in the early stages. Topic.Title: Morgan Stanley: Oppenheimer To Sell Debt And Raise Yield To 6%

Message.Msg: On Thursday, activist investors David Einhorn hosted a 1-hour conference call discussing his 'iPrefs' ideas as the best way for Apple (Nasdaq: AAPL) to unlock shareholder value. Meanwhile, analysts at Morgan Stanley went straight to one of the primary decision maker - CFO Peter Oppenheimer. Following a meeting with Mr. Oppenheimer, analyst Katy L. Huberty is convinced that Apple will: (1) increase cash return to shareholders, (2) expand carriers, distribution, and possibly price points to drive iPhone growth, and (3) improve and expand its services offerings. "Our analysis suggests Apple can match the S&P IT sector's average FCF payout of 68% if it returns $28B in FY13, implying a 6% total yield," Huberty said on shareholder returns. The company can address high mix of international cash by raising low-interest debt instead of repatriating the cash, she said. Huberty said there are several signs that a lower priced iPhone makes sense: 1) iPad Mini is expanding Apple’s customer base with 50% of purchases in China/Brazil representing new customers to the ecosystem. 2) Chinese consumers show a desire to purchase the latest version of iPhone (instead of discounted older generations). 3) iPhone 4 demand surprised to the upside in the December quarter. "Even at a low 40% gross margin and 1/3 cannibalization rate, we see an "iPhone Mini" as incremental to revenue and gross profit dollars," the analyst comments. In addition to the debate about action, the analyst said expanded services is a key to unlocking value. "With a 500M installed base of iTunes/App Store accounts, Apple has the opportunity to introduce new services that drive increased device sales, customer stickiness, and/or new revenue streams," the analyst said. "At an enterprise value per account of just $570 today (less than half of June '11 levels), these services can unlock significant value." Despite worries, the firm also said Apple's innovation pipeline is "robust." "The company’s approach to product decisions and innovation has not changed in the past several years despite the CEO transition," the analyst comments. "Making great products remains Apple’s core strategy and the company is as confident as ever about the future pipeline of new products and services." Morgan Stanley reiterated an Overweight rating and price target of $630 on Apple. Their bull case is $980 and the bear case is $400.

Message.Title: Fallacy of APPLE BEARS
Message.Msg: The Fallacy or mistaken logic in their arguments, is that: the entire market only wants the Cheapest Smartphone and Cheapest PC and Cheapest Tablets...etc. Do they themselves only drive a FIAT or Volkswagen, or a BMW or Mercedes and Lexus? A VW will also work as transportation. Do they only buy their clothes at Flea Markets or from Old Navy stores, cheaply made clothes that doesn't last? Or do they spend often 2 - 5X as much to buy the newer styles and higher quality clothes? The point is there's always a part of every market that has the money and is willing to pay MORE for a SUPERIOR product that works better, looks better and is more reliable. That is the top 15% of the Smartphone Market Apple now has In JAPAN. And since Apple can charge more for its phones mostly only focused on the top half or top 1/4 of a market, it makes the most profits. The Old 80/20 Rule in Business: "80% of the Profits come from the richer top 20% of the Customers". Or from the bigger accounts. SO this is why Apple has 72% of the profits worldwide in Smartphones, vs. Samsung only has 30%, and all the other companies have no profits. Apple doesn't need "majority Unit-Market-SHare" to make big profits. It ignores the lowest cost phones, the feature and barely smartphones, since Nokia and Samsung makes no money on those cheap phones.

Message.Title: APPLE planning a double launch.
Message.Msg: Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) is preparing to launcha new full-sized iPad with improved touchscreen technology, as well as a new MacBook Air with Retina display, according to news reports from Taiwan cited by AppleInsider. The next-generation 9.7-inch iPad will get rid of the glass-on-glass design in favor of the GF2 display technology currently being used to manufacture the iPad mini, according to the report. The device will also be similar in design to the smaller tablet, with a thinner and lighter frame. Piper Jaffray analyst Gene Munster had made similar predictions in a note to clients last week, adding that a launch event was likely before the end of April. According to the Taiwanese news report, Apple was also currently in the process of finalizing suppliers for the new tablet. It said the iPhone maker may remove Wintek from its list of suppliers, while favoring Nitto Denko, TPK, and Japan Display. Assembly would likely be done by Apple’s main manufacturing partner, Foxconn…

Message.Msg: fundamentally this stock is one of the best but technically it is now also showing a bottom. Retested previous low range of $442 and held, double bottom is in place with RSI divergence and stochastic divergence on 3 day and weekly. When if this market starts to tank new money jumps and smart money pulls back and looks for safe rocks like AAPL. Plenty of cash and it's already taken a ridiculous beating, alot of downside is out. There's only so many buyers or sellers. Which is why appl won't hit $400 and goog won't hit $1,000. Do your own analysis but fundamentally this companys always been the ace and technically its getting a stronger and stronger bounce setup. Crazy thing with stocks like these is that they are so high priced it can bounce $50 plus in a day. Look at cmg going from $266 to $315 in under a month, goog losing $50 its earnings day, or the way this thing dropped from $705 to $600 in under 2 weeks. Message.Title: Reasons to be pessimistic about Apple
Message.Msg: 1. Holding on the mountain of cash is being viewed as evidence that the company itself sees rough times ahead. 2. Insiders at Apple has historically been reluctant to espouse the notion that they're in it for the money. They hold relatively little shares. Compared to say Larry Ellison who makes a lot and rightly spends his money..and wisely IMHO. 3. No new news in the last few months....What's Jony Ivie up to? 4. No evidence of emotional response to tremendous loss in shareholder value. 5. Tepid ad/pr campaigns....makes the competition's ad campaigns look stellar. 6. So many fund managers exited that makes one wonder whether they had information. Many of these funds do not bet, they trade on info known to them. The volume of selling suggests that some people knew that there is nothing on the horizon to reverse the trend. I'm still long but beginning to wonder...

Topic.Title: pharmaherooe, just received a response from federdal trade commission regarding you..

Message.Msg: Pump-and-Dumps" and Market Manipulations "Pump-and-dump" schemes involve the touting of a company's stock (typically small, so-called "microcap" companies) through false and misleading statements to the marketplace. These false claims could be made on social media, as well as on bulletin boards and chat rooms. Pump-and-dump schemes often occur on the Internet where it is common to see messages posted that urge readers to buy a stock quickly or to sell before the price goes down, or a telemarketer will call using the same sort of pitch. Often the promoters will claim to have "inside" information about an impending development or to use an "infallible" combination of economic and stock market data to pick stocks. In reality, they may be company insiders or paid promoters who stand to gain by selling their shares after the stock price is "pumped" up by the buying frenzy they create. Once these fraudsters "dump" their shares and stop hyping the stock, the price typically falls, and investors lose their money.

Topic.Title: What wil lthe Board do on Thursday?

Message.Msg: If you mean the Einhorn suit, it simply means the items on the ballot cannot be bundled for the vote ... they can either separate them and then vote or defer it to a later date. From what I understand, the measure was only to limit the issue of PF stock in the future ... has nothing to do whether the company will or will not issue preferred stock. Einhorn can win the bundled issue and Apple can say "Great, we aren't issuing PF stock for the next 20 years so stick it" ... He is pushing it because he has 1.6 million shares. Most of us small shareholders will not see that level of benefit. The company decides what they want to do or not not the activist investors. I agree Apple needs to do something with the massive money but as it keeps building and building, it only gets better for the shareholders. Eventually it will be so big it will perpetually sustain a major dividend for our lifetimes!

Topic.Title: What wil lthe Board do on Thursday?

Message.Msg: This is exactly right. Einhorn is taking this thing one step at a time. The ballot issue with bundling the three separate items is a separate & distinct matter. Following this, Apple would have to decide whether or not to issue preferred stock, which they most likely would not. It would appear that Einhorn is taking this route to separate the preferred stock issue from the pervue of a shareholder vote, which in practice is a longer, more drawn out process. In theory, he then could approach Apple mgmt in private negotiations to work out some sort of equity payout deal. (Which of course, would be done for the benefit of his fund principally.)

Topic.Title: What wil lthe Board do on Thursday?

Message.Msg: "Well, let me first talk about your use of the word "sparingly" because this one I don't agree with. Or at least, I wouldn't use the word in the same context. We've actually spent billions in the supply chain. We've spent billions on acquisitions and including the acquisition of IP. We've spent billions on retail. We've spent billions on the infrastructure, the company, data centers and so forth for the App Store and iCloud, etc., but yes we still have a lot. I guess I'm just pointing that out to say--I would say that we're judicious; we're deliberate. We spend our money like it's our last penny. I think shareholders want us to do that. They don't want us to act like we're rich, and we've never felt that way honestly. That may sound bizarre, but it's the truth. Now, in terms of our approach on cash, I've said since becoming CEO, I'm not religious about this. I'm not religious about holding it or not holding it. And we're in very active discussions at the board level on what we should do. But I think everyone would want us to be deliberate and really think through, and that's what we're doing. We're not going to go have a toga party or do something outlandish, and so people don't have to worry it's going to burn a hole in our pocket. It was always discussed. It's not new that we're discussing it. It is being discussed more, now, and in greater detail, and that's because the balance has risen to the point that you've already made. And I think it's clear to everyone, and I'd be the first to admit, we have more cash than we need to run the business on a daily basis. I'm sure everyone would agree with that in here. And so we're actively discussing it. I only ask for a bit of patience, so that we can do this in a very deliberate way and make the best decision for the shareholders."

Message.Title: AAPL CEO QUOTE REGARDING CASH from CNN Money
Message.Msg: Well, let me first talk about your use of the word "sparingly" because this one I don't agree with. Or at least, I wouldn't use the word in the same context. We've actually spent billions in the supply chain. We've spent billions on acquisitions and including the acquisition of IP. We've spent billions on retail. We've spent billions on the infrastructure, the company, data centers and so forth for the App Store and iCloud, etc., but yes we still have a lot. I guess I'm just pointing that out to say--I would say that we're judicious; we're deliberate. We spend our money like it's our last penny. I think shareholders want us to do that. They don't want us to act like we're rich, and we've never felt that way honestly. That may sound bizarre, but it's the truth. Now, in terms of our approach on cash, I've said since becoming CEO, I'm not religious about this. I'm not religious about holding it or not holding it. And we're in very active discussions at the board level on what we should do. But I think everyone would want us to be deliberate and really think through, and that's what we're doing. We're not going to go have a toga party or do something outlandish, and so people don't have to worry it's going to burn a hole in our pocket. It was always discussed. It's not new that we're discussing it. It is being discussed more, now, and in greater detail, and that's because the balance has risen to the point that you've already made. And I think it's clear to everyone, and I'd be the first to admit, we have more cash than we need to run the business on a daily basis. I'm sure everyone would agree with that in here. And so we're actively discussing it. I only ask for a bit of patience, so that we can do this in a very deliberate way and make the best decision for the shareholders.

Topic.Title: People are bothered by AAPL's arrogance - they think cash is theirs and not shareholders'

Message.Msg: You know, personally, i AM bothered to an extent by their cash hoarding, since in principle (some of it) DOES belong to the share holders. That's the reality of a public entitiy. OTOH, a company charter is free enterprise's version of a constitution, and whether shareholders like it or not, the BOD (congress) has the right of management (leadership). The shareholder meetings are where the "public" gets to voice their rights. Einhorn is striving to remove that right, and in so doing, circumvent the public vote. He then intends to put himself in the position of a congressional "lobbyist" and song-and-dance himself in private to a suitable equity payout deal. That's why that guy Kedrosky (and others) thinks he ultimately will fail, since Apple mgmt will have no particular motivation to strike any such shareholder "deal".

THAT'S the trend that's in place, unfortunately for investors. It will be broken at some point of course, not i don't see it happening now .... notwithstanding this silly greed-driven play by Einhorn.

Message.Title: 630 target
Message.Msg: Morgan Stanley analyst Katy Huberty is offering up today's iDividend commentary, following a meeting with Oppenheimer. Based on the meeting, Huberty is now of the belief that Apple will more than double its current dividend. She suggests that Apple could easily match the S&P IT sector's average payout of 68% of free cash flow, which would translate into returning $28 billion to shareholders in fiscal year 2013. That payout would represent a total yield of approximately 6%, or nearly triple its current yield of just over 2%. That would be an unprecedented move for a company to boost its dividend by so much less than a year after initiating it. But then again, Apple's done a lot of unprecedented things over the past few years, such as accumulating an additional $100 billion in cash on its balance sheet over the past three years alone. Huberty notes that the amount of cash that sits overseas remains a challenge and limits the company's flexibility to boost its dividend by this magnitude, but adds that Apple can raise low-interest debt to partially mitigate this challenge. This is a notion that's been gaining steam lately, as it could actually lower Apple's weighted average cost of capital since Apple's cost of equity is likely in the neighborhood of 10% and debt is awfully cheap right now. Despite Apple's pullback, Huberty is keeping her rating at "overweight" and a price target of $630.
